section.title: make, let, allow
section.sectiontitle: Use make to talk about obligation imposed by another person or set of rules. Use this form: make + object + verb.
section.text1: I don't want to clean my room.
section.text1a: My father makes me clean my room
section.text2: The regulations required us to leave the building at five p.m.
section.text2a: They made us leave the building at five p.m.
section.sectiontitle2: Two forms are possible in the negative:
section.text3a: She didn't make us work very hard.
section.text4a: She never made us work very hard.

section.title: make, let, allow
section.sectiontitle: In the passive, use the infinitive with to after made.
section.text1a: We were made to clean the whole house.
section.text2a: He was made to iron his own shirts.

section.title: make, let, allow
section.sectiontitle: Use let to talk about permission, using this form: let + object + verb (without to). It is not possible to use let in the passive form.
section.text1: I want to drive the car and my mother says I can.
section.text1a: My mother lets me drive her car.
section.text2a: I'll let you borrow my coat if you want.
section.sectiontitle2: Use not let when someone doesn't have permission.
section.text3a: My father doesn't let me use his computer.
section.text4a: She wanted to stay up late but I didn't let her.

section.title: make, let, allow
section.sectiontitle: Use allow to talk about permission. Use this form: allow + object + to + verb. The meaning is similar to let.
section.text1a: My parents allow me to stay out late
section.text2a: I don't allow her to eat chocolate.
section.sectiontitle2: Allow is common in the passive form.
section.text3a: I am allowed to stay out late.
section.text4a: They weren't allowed to borrow the money.
